channel.title: Comments on: The mother of all WordPress body tags

item.title: By: mimoYmima
item.dc:creator: mimoYmima
item.description: yeah we used it for a while and it has some problems which is why we wrote this... I think the main problem was that it didn't give you a class for the parent of the page you're on, but there might have been other reasons.
item.content:encoded: yeah we used it for a while and it has some problems which is why we wrote this… I think the main problem was that it didn't give you a class for the parent of the page you're on, but there might have been other reasons.

item.title: By: mimoYmima
item.dc:creator: mimoYmima
item.description: yes it will still work, you just need to use some sort of custom permalink structure, not necessarily this exact one
item.content:encoded: yes it will still work, you just need to use some sort of custom permalink structure, not necessarily this exact one

item.title: By: Carolyn B
item.dc:creator: Carolyn B
item.description: I always delete...." /%year%/%monthnum%/%category% " .... and leave the " /%postname%/ "...so the page name displays better in the url. Will this code still work if I do that?
item.content:encoded: I always delete…." /%year%/%monthnum%/%category% " …. and leave the " /%postname%/ "…so the page name displays better in the url. Will this code still work if I do that?

item.title: By: mimoymima
item.dc:creator: mimoymima
item.description: Yeah basically that's it, you could just view the source of your page and see the class and ID that gets put on the body, you can target either of them in your css.
item.content:encoded: Yeah basically that's it, you could just view the source of your page and see the class and ID that gets put on the body, you can target either of them in your css.

item.title: By: john
item.dc:creator: john
item.description: great trick. was about to conjure something like this myself, and came across your wonderfully thoughtful solution while doing some research. thanks for sharing!
item.content:encoded: great trick. was about to conjure something like this myself, and came across your wonderfully thoughtful solution while doing some research. thanks for sharing!

item.title: By: Jay
item.dc:creator: Jay
item.content:encoded:
I'm super excited about the possibilities this code offers! I'm just not quite sure how I'd incorporate the styles in my CSS. Let's say I had site with a "Courses" page and a subsequent sub-page of: "Desktop Training". Would the styles in my style.css look like this:

#courses { blahblah: blah; }

#desktop-training { moreblah: blabla; }

Or have some other format?

Sorry if this is obvious, I really have no idea how PHP works.

Thanks so much for sharing!
